waypoints.title: The Central Molecular Zone
waypoints.description: The Central Molecular Zone (CMZ) of our Galaxy seen with MEERKAT and Spitzer. This extreme environment, 200 parsecs around our Galaxy's supermassive black hole, harbors unique phenomena impossible to study elsewhere. Color composite by Ashley Barnes.

waypoints.title: ACES Survey
waypoints.description: The ALMA Central Molecular Zone Exploration Survey (ACES) combined with the Green Bank Telescope's MUSTANG survey. This comprehensive survey has revealed unprecedented details of molecular gas dynamics and star formation in the Galactic Center, enabling the discovery of exotic objects impossible to find anywhere else.

waypoints.title: The M0.8-0.2 Ring: A Supernova's Legacy
waypoints.description: This remarkable ring-shaped molecular cloud was discovered by Nonhebel et al. (2024) in ACES data. With inner and outer radii of 3.1 and 6.1 parsecs, this structure contains ~10⁶ solar masses of gas expanding at ~20 km/s. The team proposes this is the remnant of a hypernova explosion that disrupted a massive molecular cloud, providing an extreme example of stellar feedback in the CMZ. Citation: Nonhebel et al. 2024, A&A, 691, A70

waypoints.title: The M0.8-0.2 Ring: A Supernova's Legacy - now in CS 2-1
waypoints.description: This remarkable ring-shaped molecular cloud was discovered by Nonhebel et al. (2024) in ACES data (CS 2-1 now shown). With inner and outer radii of 3.1 and 6.1 parsecs, this structure contains ~10⁶ solar masses of gas expanding at ~20 km/s. The team proposes this is the remnant of a hypernova explosion that disrupted a massive molecular cloud, providing an extreme example of stellar feedback in the CMZ. Citation: Nonhebel et al. 2024, A&A, 691, A70

waypoints.title: Back to ACES Overview
waypoints.description: Returning to the full ACES field of view to contextualize our next discovery - a mysterious compact object with extraordinarily broad molecular line emission.

waypoints.title: The MUBLO: G0.02467-0.0727
waypoints.description: The Millimeter Ultra-Broad-Line Object (MUBLO) discovered by Ginsburg et al. (2024) is unlike anything previously observed. This compact source (≲10⁴ AU) exhibits molecular line emission with extreme velocities (~160 km/s FWHM) in CS, SO, and SO₂ transitions, yet shows no signs of strong shocks. Despite extensive modeling, its nature remains a mystery - possibly representing an entirely new class of astrophysical object. Citation: Ginsburg et al. 2024, ApJL, 968, L11

waypoints.title: Sgr B2 Context
waypoints.description: For comparison, here is the well-studied Sagittarius B2 complex - our Galaxy's most massive star-forming region. The ACES survey, combined with earlier ALMA observations (Ginsburg et al. 2018), provides crucial context for understanding both normal and exotic objects in the CMZ.

waypoints.title: ACES: Revealing the Extreme Universe
waypoints.description: The ACES survey continues to reveal the extreme physics at play in our Galaxy's center. From supernova-disrupted molecular clouds to mysterious ultra-broad-line objects, these discoveries demonstrate how unique environments can produce phenomena impossible to study elsewhere in the cosmos. As the survey progresses, we expect many more surprises from this remarkable laboratory of extreme astrophysics.

waypoints.title: CH₃CHO: Acetaldehyde
waypoints.description: Acetaldehyde (CH₃CHO) is a complex organic molecule that traces warm, dense gas in star-forming regions. Its emission reveals sites of active chemistry and heating in the CMZ.

waypoints.title: CS 2-1: Carbon Monosulfide
waypoints.description: Carbon monosulfide (CS) is an excellent tracer of dense molecular gas. The 2-1 transition reveals the distribution of high-density regions throughout the ACES field.

waypoints.title: H¹³CN: Hydrogen Cyanide Isotopologue
waypoints.description: H¹³CN is a rare isotopologue of hydrogen cyanide that traces dense molecular gas without becoming optically thick, providing crucial measurements of gas column density.

waypoints.title: H¹³CO⁺: Formyl Ion Isotopologue
waypoints.description: H¹³CO⁺ traces ionized molecular gas and reveals regions where UV radiation or cosmic rays are ionizing the molecular material, probing the interaction between stars and gas.

waypoints.title: H40α: Hydrogen Recombination Line
waypoints.description: The H40α recombination line traces ionized hydrogen around hot, massive stars, revealing sites of ongoing massive star formation in the Galactic Center.

waypoints.title: HC₁₅N: Cyanopolyyne
waypoints.description: HC₁₅N is a long-chain carbon molecule that traces cold, quiescent molecular gas, helping identify regions that have not yet been heated by star formation.

waypoints.title: HC₃N: Cyanoacetylene
waypoints.description: Cyanoacetylene (HC₃N) is a carbon-chain molecule that traces cold molecular gas and is abundant in quiescent regions of molecular clouds.

waypoints.title: HCO⁺: Formyl Ion
waypoints.description: HCO⁺ is one of the most important tracers of ionized molecular gas. Its emission reveals the structure and kinematics of dense gas throughout the CMZ.

waypoints.title: HCO⁺: Mopra Single-Dish
waypoints.description: HCO⁺ observed with the Mopra telescope provides large-scale structure context for the ALMA observations, showing the full extent of ionized gas.

waypoints.title: HCO⁺: Interferometer Only
waypoints.description: HCO⁺ without total power data shows only the compact structures resolved by ALMA's interferometer, revealing the small-scale structure of dense cores.

waypoints.title: HN¹³C: Hydrogen Isocyanide Isotopologue
waypoints.description: HN¹³C, an isotopologue of hydrogen isocyanide, traces dense gas while avoiding optical depth effects, allowing accurate measurement of gas masses.

waypoints.title: HNCO: Isocyanic Acid
waypoints.description: HNCO traces warm molecular gas and is often enhanced in shocked regions. This map combines 7m, 12m, and total power data for complete spatial coverage.

waypoints.title: NS⁺: Nitrogen Sulfide Ion
waypoints.description: NS⁺ is a rare molecular ion that traces regions with active ion-molecule chemistry, providing insights into the chemical networks operating in the CMZ.

waypoints.title: SiO 2-1: Silicon Monoxide
waypoints.description: SiO is a shock tracer that highlights regions where high-velocity gas collisions have liberated silicon from dust grains, revealing outflows and cloud collisions.

waypoints.title: SO 2₁-1₀: Sulfur Monoxide
waypoints.description: SO traces moderately dense gas and is often enhanced in shocked regions and outflows, complementing SiO as a probe of energetic processes.

waypoints.title: SO 3₂-2₁: Sulfur Monoxide
waypoints.description: The SO 3₂-2₁ transition traces warmer and denser gas than SO 2₁-1₀, providing information about temperature and density variations in shocked regions.
